newsitem.title: CANADA: Bank Montreal sets small business loan plan.
newsitem.headline: Bank Montreal sets small business loan plan.

text.p: Bank of Montreal said on Tuesday it has set up a C$1 billion loan program to spur growth of Canadian small and medium-sized businesses by offering fixed-rate loans at lower interest rates.
Canada's third-largest bank said it will provide loans of between C$10,000 and C$250,000 for terms of three to five years and may be amortized for periods up to 15 years.
The loans are for credit-worthy small businesses to use for purposes such as buying new equipment or financing expansion plans, the bank said.

"More than 95 per cent of our business customers are small to medium-sized companies with annual revenues of less than $10 million. As they grow, they reach a critical point where they need financing to seize current market opportunities," said Maurice Hudon, senior vice-president of Bank of Montreal's personal and commercial lending services.
The new loan funding will increase by 12 percent the C$8 billion in credit already outstanding to small business, the bank said.
Bank of Montreal has grown its share of the small business loan market by six percent in the past six years.
The new financing program allows borrowers to fix their interest rate for the full term of the loan, and receive a significant discount in the first year.

The rate of the first year is 4.90 percent, a rate which will apply to all loans made up to June 30, 1997. The rates thereafter will be set according to market conditions with the first year rate established at a discount. The program will be in effect until January 31, 1998.
